div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definaitely engaged beforehand: Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monda.A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving inLondon at the very convenient hour of 4.56.p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fair is £22.9.11 Port Said to London vis Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leaves Suez for Aden and Bombay every WEdnesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE
div.p: A Havas telegram from Algeciras, which we publish to-day, announces that Germany has refused to entertain the French proposal regarding the policing of Morocoo by French and Spanish officers selcted by the Sultan.

Germany bases her non pouumus attitude on the fact that to permit such a scheme would be oontrary to the internationalisation of the country and the equality of the Powers there. As the conference may come to pieces on this question it is important to consider it, especially in view of the new light thrown on the subject by the statements which I appeared in the "Times" of yesterday week. It will be remembered that a recent "inspired” communique to the German Press gave it to be understood that France had claimed the right to police the whole of Morocco, a claim against which Germany had protested, and would protest, on the ground that it infringed the principle of the Sultan’s independence, and would lead to the "Tunisification” of the She- reefian Empire. Now as the Paris correspondent of the "Times” pointed out yesterday week. M. Revoil has never made any each claim on behalf of h’s Government—we shall see, present¬ly, why not. Ail that France claims is, as M. Revoil has made it dear, the right to organise the policing of the ports, and it is round the problem of organizing the necessary police force for the seaports that the struggle is going on behind the screen of diplomatic decency inter-posed by the formal meetings over which the Duke of Almodovar presides.

Why is that particular problem the only one for which M. Revoil would have been likely to claim, as he has done, the right of France to find the necessary solution ? The answer is - simple enough. The penetration of the civilising influence in Morocco must proceed, as the . anatomists say, from without inwards. The fringe of Moroccan seaports formas the row of doors by which Moroccao communicates (in so far as she is compelled to do so) with Europe on the north and on the west These towns contain considerable European populations engaged in trader or owning laud in the vicinity. Outside the zone of the influence of these towns reigns immemorial chaos, which extends over the rest of the land, right away to the Algerian frontier on the east, and south¬wards to the sands of the Sahara. Can any sane person imagine that France has any desire to attempt the subjugation—for that it would have to be — manu military of an enormous country, absolutely unprovided with roads, and inhabited by fierce, fighting tribesmen, who dare not, if they could, grow more corn and other necessaries than they actually want, for fear of the rapacity either of neighbours or of the local governors in those of their districts where these feel themselves able to practice extortion ? Years hence the interior of Morocco may gradually yield to the process of more or less practise penetration; but for the present it is enough to attempt to civilise the coasts—a proofs of which European interests m the seaports have long been in sore need. Now, considering that Germany's interests in Marocco have been officially declared to be purely commercial, (though these amount to only about £90,000 worth of trade per annum) one might have supposed that such interests would have been admirably served by the prompt inauguration of a system which would guarantee the security of life and property in and around the ports. But not a bit of it: the German proposal, we are told, is that the Sultan shall do the work, with the assistance of the minor powers. That would mean, of course, that there would be no efficient organisation what¬ever. France, with her Algerian experience, with her Algerian prestige, is the obvious agent to be selected by Europe for the job; hot Germany, it seems, will not consent Wby? Because, as as it would appear, she prefers the continuance of the present state of things to a change which would put an everlasting veto upon the ambition which she cherishes, but does not avow, of securing a foothold on the Atlantic seaboard herself She knows that, for the present, that ambition cannot be realised, bat she holds on to it, knowing that every¬thing comes to those who know how to wait, and that, since she cannot get her own way yet, the next best thing is to keep the door open, and bide her time until circumstances, shall allow her to slip in. Those circumstances?, however, will hardly be present just yet But the German game scarcely bodes well for the success of the Morocco Conference.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Motor Car Tax
The new tax of L.E. 5 per annum on motor earn in Alexandria is arousing some dissatisfac­tion.
Investment and Agency.
The balance sheet of the Egyptian Invest­ment and Agency will appear in tomorrow’s issue.
Wakfs Administration.
The Council of the Wakfs Administration will meet this afternoon in Cairo, under the presidency of Abd El Halim Pacha Assem.
Generous Gift.
H. H. Prince Mogamed Aly Ibrahim has presented a sum of L.E. 200 to the Alexandria Moslem Benevolent Society, El Orwat El
Woska.
Government Pension Fund.

Mr. G. H. Ryan, general manager of the Pelican and British Empire Life Office, is in consultation with the Egyptian Government on the matter of its pension fond, and will shortly come to Egypt in connection with the question.
The Abyssinian Bank.

The London Stock Exchange Committee have appointed a special settling day as under: Thursday, March 1 Bank of Abyssinia, English scrip for 7 O'X) shares of £5 each. £3 5s. paid (of which £2 is premium and £1 5s. capital).
P. W. D. Salaries.

The Ministry of Public Works has decided to increase the salaries of Mr. Tottenham, assistant inspector ; Mr. Welsh, assistant engineer; and Saleh Eff., accountant, of the Sudan Irrigation Department, to L.E. 700, , L.E. 360, and L.E. 240 respectively.
Port Sudan.

Port Su an will be built on the American in blocks of a hundred meters square each, which may be subdivided into still blocks. The European town will be separated from the native one by an empty space half a kilometre wide.
Nile Navigation.

The Irrigation Service has decided to construct a sadd across the Damietta branch of the Nile at Farascur near Damietta. The public is therefore warned that navigation on the Damietta branch of the Nile will be interrup­ted at Farascur, from the 1st August
Pyjamas Act like Medicine.

The visit of a king his wife, and his mother- in-law to a steamer on the Nile is well described in "Blackwood.” The mother-in-law was "a poor, withered, crinkled old crone, crippled with rheumatism, and half-starved. She was made happy, deliriously so, with a suit of pyjamas.”
The Rudolph Home.

We have received from Mr. E E. Charruy, manager of the Societe de Pressage et des Depots, £1 on behalf of the Rudolph Home in memory of the late Hans de Tschudi. M. Jacques I. and M. Joseph I. Aghion have each contributed £1 and Mr. A. Q. M Dickson P.T. l00.
Washington’s Birthday.

The Hon. Mr. Iddings, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, and Mrs. Iddings will be “At Home” at the Agency, situated at Kasr-el-Doubara, to-morrow (Wednesday) after­noon, on the occasion of the anniversary or Washington’s birthday, and they will be pleased to see any American residents or visitors who may desire to call on that day.
Khedivial Geographical Sociaty.

Mr. M. Cram, an administrative officer of the Belgian Congo, and chief of the Lake Albert territory, will give a lecture to the Khedivial Geographical Society on Saturday next on the regions of the Equatorial fakes (where he has lived for over three years), the inhabitants, the sources of the Nile, and the great problems of African colonisation.
Life in the Sudan.

At a lonely telegraph station established on the banks of the Nile, above Khartoum, recently the operative, an Egyptian, wired in horror to Khartoum staging he was surrounded by lions, leopards, hyenas, and beam. There­after, bethinking himself that the genus Ursus was not represented in the Sudan, he telegraphed again. ‘Delete bears,” ran his second wire, for if terrified he was conscientious.
Egyptian Trust and Investment

Robert Logan, managing director in London of the National Bank of New Zealand, and Mr. Charles C. Perkins, of Messrs. Barclay, Perkins and Co., arrived at Alexandria by the North German Lloyd steamer. Both these gentlemen are the directors of the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Lin ted and we under­stand that their visit to Egypt, which will be of very short duration, is in connection with the development of the company’s business.

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES
div.p: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE
WILL IT BREAK DOWN?
(Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON, Tuesday

It is generally considered that unless the impending visit of Baron de Courcel to Berlin brings a decisive change in the situation, the present tension must continue, with the result that the Algeciras Conference will completely breakdown. The reason is that Germany has quite refused to entertain France’s propositions on the subject of the organisa­tion of the police force in Morocco. France wants Morocco’s policing to be entrusted to ; her and Spain jointly This is said to be the final concession which France is prepared to make in this matter.

div.head: MR. BALFOUR AND THE CITY
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON, Tuesday
Mr. Gibson Bowles has agreed to oppose Mr. Balfour’s candidature for the City of London

div.head: THE PRINCE'S TOUR
div.p: (Gazette’s Special Service.)
London. Tuesday.
Owing to an outbreak of cholera on the borders of Nepaul the Prince of Wales’s tiger shooting expedition has had to be abandoned.

div.head: AN ECHO OF TRAFALGAR
div.p: (Gazette’s Special Service.)
London, Tuesday.

A very interesting naval discovery has been , made of a document, which has been lost for a , hundred years. It is a general memorandum, containing the instructions issued by Nelson in his own handwriting to the captains before going into action at Trafalgar

div.head: PRINCE OF WALES' VISIT
div.p: Arrangements are already being made at the Ghazireh Palace Hotel for the reception of the suite of T.R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales, during their stay in Cairo. They are expected to arrive about the last week in March.

div.head: THE FRONTIER INCIDENT
div.p: A native contemporary states that the reported dismissal of the commandant of Akaba is a groundless rumour, and that the Turkish Government has decided to forward 10,000 more troops to Akaba, where some new fortifications are to be built.

div.head: OPERA HOUSE ACCIDENT
div.p: The accident to the Khedivial Opera House has had unpleasant consequences. The scenery of Aida.Tosca, Iris, and Traviata has suffered damage from water, the machinery has suffered, and the stage and orchestra too. The electric installation was not repaired on Sunday eight.

The ingenious employe of the Wa' er Company, who appears to have taken "apres moi le deluge” as his motto, has the satisfaction of knowing that he has caused a mild sensation and much material damage, and has landed the company which he represents in an action for damages brought by the Cercle Artistique, which has at the same time announced its intention of suing the Egyptian Government. It is hoped that Iris will be given tonight.

div.head: MOSLEM NEW YEAR'S DAY.
div.p: As the Mohamedan New Year’s Day (24th inst.) falls during the absence of H.H. the Khedive on his excursion in the desert, visitors may call at Abdeen Palace on that day and enter their names in the register of the Khedivial Cabinet of Ceremonies.

T H. the Khedivah and the Khedivah Mother will hold a reception, on New Year’s Day at Koubbeh Palace as follows:—Prom 9 a.m. to 11.30 a.m. for princesses and native ladies ; from 3 p.m. to 4.15 p.m. for European ladies, and at 4.15 p.m. for the wives of diplo­matic agents.

div.head: THE LATE MR. H. DE TSOHUDI
div.p: The funeral of Mr. Hans von Tschudi took place at Alexandria this morning, the funeral procession starting at about 9.30 o’clock from the Deaconesses’ Hospital. There was a large and representative gathering present, includ¬ing the Consular Corps and Mr. E. B. Gould, 18.0., and a number of members of the British Colony. There were seven landaus filled with flowers. The funeral service was conducted according to the Lutheran rite.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: THE ELECTIONS
THE SUCCESSFUL CANDIDATES

The election for the General College took place at the Bourse yesterday amidst marked apathy. Out of over 1,400 electors only 842 recorded their vote, and of this number over half were taken from their offices and shops in motors and private carriages. All the four can¬didates elected were in the first list, while the unsuccessful candidates were Mr. Zonro, Dr. Lisaridis, Mr. Achilles Abbat, and Mahmoud Ghimei. The votes gained by the successful candidates were : Mr. Michael Salvago, 632 ; Mr. Tambacopoulo, 579 ; Mr. H. P Kingham, 5 2 ; and Dr. Valensin. 552. Mr, Zouro headed the second list with 231 votes, Mr. Achilles Abbat obtained 139 Dr Lascaridis 135, and Mahmoud Ghimei 95. Mr. Kingham and Dr. Valensin having obtained an equal number of votes, they cast lots who should replace Mr. G. B. Alderson for his unexpired tenure of office. Dr. Valensin was the winner, so he will; remain at the Municipality for four years, while Mr. Kingham will obtain Mr. Alderson’s unexpired tenure.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK
div.p: Mr. Rowlatt, Sub-Governor of the National Bu-k of Egypt at Cairo, has been appointed Governor of the Bank.

Mr. Frederick Terry Rowlatt celebrated his forty first birthday a few days ago. He is the son of the late A. H. Rowlatt, one of Egypt's earlier prominent bankers, and was born at Alexandria. He was educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, where he was known both as a soho ar and a sportsman, and from where be carried off several prizes for swimming. He entered the Bank of Egypt in London in 1885 and was transferred to the Egyptian branch, of which he acted as manager, and he gave up that pout to become sub-governor of the National flank. He became a Fellow of the Institute of Bankers, London, in 1902. He married Edith, daughter of Mr. Cornish, C.M.G, of Alexandria, in May, 1905.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS AGAIN!
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Helouan, Monday.

Soma excitement was caused in Helouan to day on the arrival of the mid-day train from Cairo, by an attack made upon a gentle­man resident in the town who had travelled by the train and was proceeding homewards. The assailant carried a thick stick with which: he dealt the gentleman a terrific blow in the face, causing an ugly wound which bled profusely. The assistance of the police having been obtained, the assailant was taken to the police station. The gentleman attacked, having given an account of the occurrence, was astounded at being informed that the police could neither arrest nor detain his assailant on account of his being a Spanish subject. The man was consequently liberated, and may easily have left the country before the consular law can be put in motion. Something should be done, undoubtedly, to ensure the safety of life and limb and the interests of justice in such cases.

div.head: THE CAB STRIKE AND TARIFF
div.p: This morning Mr. Fabri, a cabowner, was to have been charged with inciting others to commit breaches of the peace during the recent cab strike at Alexandria. The case, which was to have been heard before the British Consular Court was withdrawn.

A great amount of dissatisfaction has been aroused among the public of Alexandria by the surrender of the Municipality to the demands of the cabmen The new tariff is considered very high. For example, a two-horse carriage now costs P.T. 5 for half an hour instead of P.T. 6 for an hour. The whole basis of the new tariff shows a large increase and it is presumed that the Municipality have decided on these increases so as not to forego the great increase in the tax on the users of the unnumbered carriages.

div.head: DAHAN PROPERTY SOLD
div.p: We understand that the Dahan building in Ramleh-boulevard, Alexandria, where the Bri­tish Consume Was previously located, has been purchased by Mr. Aug. van Millingen, proprie­tor of the Windsor Hotel. It is Mr. Millingen’s intention to transfer his hotel to his new property, where considera le structural altera­tions will be carried out in order to make it a first-class hotel in every respect. The ground floor will be entirely reconstructed, the present rooms making way for a grand entrance, dining room, bar, reception-room, etc. Lifts will be Installed and every modern convenience will be added to make the hate one of the finest in Egypt
We believe that the purchase price was £40,000. As is usual nowadays in this country, Mr. Millingon was immediately afterwards offered £4.000 more for the property, but has declined the offer.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Papayanni liner Falernian left Malta last evening and is expected to arrive here with passengers and mails on Friday next.

div.head: PORT SAID NOTES
div.p: FANCY DRESS BALL
ATTENDANCE NEARLY ALL ENGLISH
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
Port Said, Saturday

The fancy dress ball, in aid of the funds of the Port Said Sporting Club, given on the 10th inst., was a great success. We are not yet in a position to say bow much the club has gained financially by the function, hot no doubt quite a respectable sum will go into the treasurer's coffers. In view of the fact that the Sporting Club will be "international,” it is regrettable j that the different colonies, of which Port Saidsociety is composed, were not more numerously represented. A casual glance round the spacious ballroom sufficed to show that practi­cally the entire attendance was English. There was not so much animation and gaiety, as once usually expects to see at a masked ball, and those who ventured forth in fancy dress did not distinguish themselves, either by the beauty or originality of their dresses.

The Governor, H.E. Mustapha lbadi Pacha, , entertained a party to supper, and several other other smaller parties partook of the excellent fare provided by the Savoy Hotel. It was not until nearly 4 a.m. that the last of the pleasure-seekers left the hall.

div.head: Russian Cruisers.
div.p: The first class Russian cruiser Bogatyr arriv¬ed here some days ago, and is still anchored in the port This vessel looks in much better condition than the others which recently passed through, and has quite a formidable appearance. It is supposed she will remain here until the arrival of the Russia and Gromoboi.

div.head: Dinner on Board
div.p: The Commandant of H.M.S. Minerva gave a dinner on Wednesday evening on board, the following being present: H. E Mustapha Ibadi Pacha, Governor of the Suez Canal ; Mr. D. A. Cameron, H. B. M. Consul General ; and Miralai I. Schalch Bey, Commandant of the SUEZ Canal Police.

div.head: Drame Passionel
div.p: On Thursday morning another of those "love and jealousy dramas” occurred here. A Belgian, 30 years of age, made a savage ; attack on a woman named Rejane, who appears to have been the man’s mistress, but had recently declared that she would no longer have anything to do with him. So last Thursday the victim received a call from her former lover, and just as he appeared on the point of departing, he made a sudden attack and inflicted several severe outs with a razor. The woman was conveyed to the hospital and is now reported to be progressing favourably. The ‘hero of the drama,” as this would-be murderer is called here, endeavoured to poison himself at the caracol, but an antidote was administered in good time and his condition is not considered dangerous. He now states that he merely intended to disfigure his victim, — not to kill her. The Belgian Consul is awaiting instructions from the Diplomatic Agentin Cairo; in the meantime, the prisoner will be kept under arrest by the local authorities.

div.head: Thwn Caged In
div.p: The new wall, and grilled railings, that are being erected along the Marina, by the Suez Canal Co., will certainly be a great improve¬ment on the old wooden pilings. But why should Port Said be caged in ? The majority of residents here already feel their isolated position keenly enough, but the new barriers, when completed, will certainly only add to the depression. The view from the water will give one the impression that Port Said is a huge quarantine park, or, may be a stranger will mistake the town for a "leper-colony.” People are ever ready to say all the bad things they ; can about Port Said; some speak from experience others from hearsay. But when the powers that be go it the trouble and expense of raising so impenetrable a barrier, they are inviting the delicate irony of our critics. If the object of the wall and high railings is to prevent smuggling, it should prove a huge success, bat if, as many are inclined to think, it is a serious attempt to beautify the town, we must look upon it as the failure of a good intention.

div.head: NOTES FROM MENA
div.p: The Mena House Hotel season is now in full swing. The weather is delightful and b3tter than it has been for years. Visitors staying there take a keen interest in outdoor sport, snob as paper chases, croquet, and golf. On Wednesday, 21st, and Friday, 23rd inst., a golf handicap will be held, prizes being present¬ed to the winners. Competitors from Cairo should send in their names on or before the 21st. A paper chase will be held on Thursday, 22 d inst. The hares will be allowed 5 minutes law only. P«ins for *ha winners will be given in this as well.
To amuse those who stay behind, Bracale’s Orchestra will perform the following programme in the peasant hotel grounds :
Marche—Italy—Minoliti
Valse—Les Sirenes—Waldteufel
Fantaisie—Carmen—Bizet Chanson du Printemps—Mendelssohn Mazurka—La Czarina—Gaune
Marche—Bismarck—Chapius
Valse—Gesohiohten aus dem Wiener Wald—Strauss
Overture—Domino Noir—Auber
Selection—The Mikado—Sullivan
Gavotte celebre—Sulli
Potpourri—Die Fledermaus—Strauss
Le Negrs siffeur—Duwin

div.head: Egyptian Art
div.p: THE IMITATIVE PERIOD
LECTURE BY PROF. FLINDERS PETRIE
The first of a series of lectures on Egyptian Art was delivered yesterday afternoon at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, by Prof. Flinders Petrie.

These lectures are given, like those of two veers ago, in aid of the Anglo-American Hospital and the Church Poor Fund. We hope that residents and visitors will thus help these institutions, as well as improve their acquaint­ance with ancient Egypt, by attending these lectures, the tickets for which can be Lad separately at all the hotels.

The first lecture was on that period of Imitative Art from the XIX h dynasty til’ Roman times. Prof. Petrie remarked that, though the art of Ancient Egypt is more or less familiar to everyone, yet it is generally credited with the style which is only the latent and least original form which it assumed. Its long history is ignored, and only its worst phase is commonly recognised. The cause of this misunderstanding is clear. The latest buildings were those which survived most completely. They attracted the attention of the European copyists by their preservation, and hence the early publications filled the popular view with the great temples of the base epoch. Then worse has followed ; for bad copies of this bid work have been placed be­fore our eyes for trade purposes, until the vilest parodies have come to be accepted as representing ancient Egypt to the public mind. What is commonly called Egyptian decoration is worse than the worst debasement which ever took place anciently.

The same misunderstanding took place in regard to Creak Art. In became known through Roman conies ; and our great-grandfathers were brought up on the worst taste of the later Roman empire, and made yet worse conies of it That stage of knowledge is much like the public acquaintance with Egypt at present Since that the good Roman work came to be appreciated; and at present all Roman copies are looked on as only indica­tions of what we have lost of the great age of Greek rt; and our understanding of it is drawn from the original son roes of the creative age of Pericle, and the still earlier time. It is such an appreciation of the true value and character of Egyptian Art, as opposed to the late degradation of it, that wilt be brought forward in these lectures.

We shall deal with three main ages of art. The most familiar age, that of the late works, is our subject, today, and it is best understood in general. It was the age of imitative art, when there was no hope for good work except in the copying of what went before it. The earlier age of conscious art, and of scholarly training in art, we shall consider next week. And the really formative period and sponta­neous art will be best understood after considering the more familiar periods.

The beginning of the Imitative period is in the works of Rameses II. That sovereign is best known by his profusion of monuments ; but all of them were hopeless imitations, when they were not direct thefts of earlier works. We fee in them the stiffness of mechanical copying by rule ; and the weakness of mere smooth finish is se«n under his successors. Rameses III., unable to avoid coarseness, tried to give the virtues of his failings by an attempt at strength in the use of deep shadow.

“The methods of training the artists can be seen in the drawings and carvings of students which have been preserved, snob as the heads and figures of kings, and one observant sketch of a youngpeasant. Through the weakness of the later work a certain anility is seen for conventional expression, and some of the wooden faces of coffins are graceful and refined.
“In statuary, good traditions may be seen mixed with clamminess of attitude and pose, as in the gold statuette of Hershefi and tbe statue of Amenardas.

In the XXVIth dynasty the traditional relief fell to a very low condition ; but improvement was sought by direct copying of older work. In the«e copies the detail may be almost indistinguishable trom that of early times, bat the lack of pose and unity of the figures at once betrays the copyist. The overloading with detail also shows the lack of originality.

"The statuary of the age is better ; but its success is largely due to using hard stones, with mechanical finish and precision of surfaces. The animal figure appear to ns better than the me”, bat that may be due to oar closer appreciation of the human figure. The polished basalt figures of the hippopotamus goddess, the cow, and others in the Cairo Museum show this. Portraiture evidently attracted the best artists, probably because it was better paid for, as in modern times

"Under the Ptolemies the work is still poorer. The limbs are mechanically put together with­out any true connection, as in the Philotera in the Vatican. The work was entirely a matter of joining together so many separate parts by mechanical rules. In order to give some effect, every part was exaggerated in an absurd manner, much like the degraded taste shewn in the Farnese Hercules The power of portraiture was the last surviving trace of Egyptian Art, as is seen on some stucco heads of coffins.

"The late architecture shows the same faults of mechanical conving ; but new motives were sought for, as at Esneh. Some skill in graceful design still continued, such as the pavilion of Trajan at Philse. The last survival of the old style of building is the Deivel Abyad at Sohag where as late as the IV’h century A D the temple type was adapted to a Christian Church. It is to be helped that this most interesting monument will be most minutely conserved in the coming repairs which are now promised

It is an ungrateful task to point out the deficiencies of the work which usually passesas typical of Egypt hot it is only by contrast­ing this with what went before it that we can see how much, greater Egyptian Art was than is commonly supposed from the familiar examples. That contrast will be described in the lectures on the Conscious and the Spontaneous Art, on the following Monday.”

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: One of the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel is Prince Chakrabongs of Siam, a younger brother of the Crown Prince, who was staying at the same hotel two years ago and who has seen so much of English life. Prince Chakrabongs is still quite a lad, but has already made himself popular. Shya Shridha- masasna, Minister of Siam at Athens, is with his party.

Prince Deimitri Ghika and Princess Mavro- cordato, from Bucharest, are also staying at the Savoy, and other visitors at this popular hotel are Count Franz von Nasdaky of Hungary and the Count and Countess de Vaureal from Paris. The Baron do de Tide Winekler, with the Countess de Qrote, mother of Baron Rucker-Jenisoh, have also arrived in Cairo and are making the Savoy their headquarters.
Lieut. Colonel Count Gleichen, D. S. O., has been appointed Military Attach* at Washington, vice Colonel Foster, B E.

Sir Stephen Mackenzie, the celebrated phy­sician, is at present at Assouan, where he is staying at the Savoy Hotel. As a student of the Universities of Aberdeen and Berlin and of Christ’s Hospital and London Hospital, Sir Stephen Mackenzie showed very gnat promise and his fame as a physician is now world-wide. Though he has published no separate work Sir Stephen has contributed not a few articles to the various well-known medi­cal dictionaries, notably those of Quain and Clifford Allbutt, and Heath and the medical periodic. In frequently receive articles from his pen. He is, as most of ns know, senior physi­cian to the London Hospital, where he was formerly lecturer on medicine, and the Royal London Ophthalmic Hospital claims his atten­tion as physician.

Mr. Bellamy Storer, Ambassador for the United States in Vienna, and Mrs. Bellamy Storer left Cairo yesterday for an extended trip up the Nile. Their party includes Princess Louise Radziwill, Miss Edith Perry, and Mr. Joseph Longworth Nichols. They will travel by rail as far as Assiout, where they will join a dahabieh.
Sir David Hunter, K. C. M. G., ex-general manager of the Natal Government railways, is on his way to England. He is travelling by the East coast, and proposes staying for a few weeks in Egypt.
Sir Horace and Lady Pinching will return to Cairo at the end of the month.
Dr. A. Granville has been appointed 1st- class inspector to the Department of Public Health.
Dr. Meiuecke, the well known German bacteriological expert, has been attached to the same Department.
Mrs. John Evans has left Biarritz for a tour in Egypt end expects to return to the Villa Sans Pareille in the Spring.
M. Nicolas Salvago and Stephano Salvago have each purchased a 24 horse power Mors automobile. Rothschild et Fils have been ins­tructed to build coupe limousine bodies for these vehicles.
Mrs Norman-Lee arrived to-day at Alex­andria by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal, and has gone back to her old quarters at the Miramare Hotel.

President George V. Chauncey, of the Mechanics' Bank, at Court and Montague streets, and of the Brooklyn Warehouse and Storage Company, in Schermerhorn street, with Mrs. Chauncey are on their way on the White Star Republic for Italy and Egypt The Chauncey expect to meet in Genoa Vice-President Horace C. Da Val, of the bank, and Mrs. Du Val, for a few hours, returning from a tour in Italy, and will themselves spend six or eight weeks in that country and along the Mediterra¬nean coast upon their return in April and May.

The King has been pleased to give and grant unto John Edwin Marshall, Esq., Judge in the Egyptian Native Court of Appeal, his Majesty's royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Third Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khe¬dive, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Saltan in recognition of valuable services rendered by him.
Mr. James Gooding, of the Middle Temple, barrister-at-law, has been admitted by the Mixed Bar Council to practise in the Appeal and other Mixed Courts.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Saturday : Mr. Cox and party of 2. Mr. and Mrs. C. Stephen, Dr. Love, Dr. Beddoe Mr. Singer. M. and Mme. Marquis de Angeres, Mr. Sinnot Hanna, Bimbachi Blerowe, Miralai Blunt, Mr. Alex­andria, Mr. Rosental, Mr. Philippe, Capt. Malin, Mr. Goussard, Mr. Waste, Birch Pacha, Mr. Webb.

div.head: KING'S SPEECH
div.p: NO SURPRISES
REFERENCES TO IRELAND.
London, February 19.

The King’s Speech, after referring to the lamented death of King Christian, says that “the Prince and Princess of Wales are visiting m many portions of my vast Indian Empire as time admits. The reception afforded them by all els8968 has been mist gratifying to me. 1 trust that the visit will tend to strengthen among my Indian subjects loyalty to the Crown and attachment to this country.”

Relations with foreign coin tries continue friendly. His Majesty rejoices that the war between Russia and Japan has resulted in an honourable peace. The Speech mentions, with out comment, the conclusion of a new Anglo- Japanese Agreement His Majesty earnestly hopes that the negotiations at Algeciras will be conducive to the maintenance of peace be­tween all nations The Speech records briefly the accession of King Hakon and Queen Maud and the appointment of reform commissioners In Crete.
His Majesty trusts that the international financial commission will lead to salutary reforms in Macedonia.

A new constitution with responsible govern­ment for the Transvaal will be drawn up. This will delay the elections for a few months beyond July : meanwhile no further licenses for the importation of Chinese will be issued. A responsible government will also be granted to the Orange River Colony. “My earnest hope is that the grant of free institutions may be followed by an increase of prosperity and loyalty to the Empire.”
The Colonial Conference has been postponed until early in 1907.
Imports continue to show a steady and until early 1907

Imports continue to show a steady and accelerating increase and together with the growing activity in the home trade, indicate that the British industries are in a sound progressive condition. The Speech calls atten­tion to the growing national expenditure and says that Ministers are considering plans for improving and effecting economies in the Go­vernment of Ireland and for introducing therein means for associating the people with the conduct of affairs. My desire is that the government of the country, in reliance of ordinary law, may be carried on in a spirit regardful of the wishes and sentiments to the Irish people.
Measures are being considered for attracting people to the land.

The Speech announces the introduction of Bills to amend education, for dealing with trade disputes, amending workmen’s compensa­tion, equalising rates in the Metropolis, and amending the Unemployed Act. (Reuter)

div.head: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE
div.p: FRENCH PROPOSAL REJECTED
Algeciras, February 19.

Germany’s reply rejects the proposal made by France that the police officers to be chosen by the Sultan should be French and Spanish. Germany declares that this proposal is contrary to the principle of internationalisation and the equality of all the Powers in Morocco (Havas)
Algeciras, February 20.

Germany suggests that the police should be under the supervision of the diplomatic body at Tangier, while France intimates that she will accept a foreign but not a German inspector general, who will be the intermediary between the Powers and the police organisation.(Reuter)

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY
div.p: Copenhagen, February 19.
The Emperor William received Baron de Courcel, the French special envoy, on board the Garman warship. Showing him marked courtesy. (Reuter)

div.head: UNEASINESS IN NATAL
div.p: London February 19.
Considerable uneasiness continues to prevail in Natal : the Europeans have constructed laagers in several places. (Reuter)

div.head: GREECE AND ROUMANIA
div.p: Athens, February 19.

A great meeting has been held here to pro­test against Roumanian action in expelling Greeks from Roumania. The Government does not participate in the movement, declaring that it is striving to obtain a direct understanding with Roumania. (Reuter)

div.head: DISSOLUTION OF HUNGARIAN CHAMBER
div.p: Paris, February 19.
The Chamber has been dissolved. Soldiers are guarding the doors. (Havas)

div.head: MORE EARTHQUAKES
div.p: London, February 19
Earthquakes have also taken place in Jamaica and Saint Vincent. In the last-named the shocks were particularly severe. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH COUNCIL
div.p: Paris, February 19.
The “Journal Official” contains a decree reappointing all the ministers. (Havas)

This prospectus has been filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: The Company has been formed for the purpose of (inter alia) carrying on business as Engineers Contractors and Builders, and the undertaking of irritation, railway, canal, marine, sewage, and constructional engineering, and public works of all kinds.

In consequence of the growth of the trade and the increase of the wealth in Egypt, and the consequent raising of the standard of living among all classes, and the steady increase in the population, the building industry in Egypt has been extraordinarily active within recent years ; and it is reasonable to suppose that the activity will be at least well maintained, if not increased, in the future. Engineering and building operations of all kinds are in progress throughout the country. Large sums of money are to be expended on public works. Private h on 80s, flits and offices are on all sides being erected, and the demand for snob buildings is ever increasing.
The following is an extract from the note by the Financial Adviser on the Budget for 1906 :—

“Roughly speaking, it may be said that Egypt is actually spending from L.E. 300,000 to L.E. 400,000 annually on public buildings ; not, I think, an extravagant sum, having regard to the revenue of the country and the fact that everything has to be provided ab initio, hospitals, post offices, prisons, asylums, schools, police stations, to say nothing of Gouvernorats, and other Government build­ings of practically every description.
“Of course in the above figures are not included great works of public utility of a remunerative nature, which are charged to Reserve Fund.”

With the working capital at its command, the Company will be in a position to take full advantage of the increasing prosperity of the country, and to undertake engineering and building con tracts of the largest kind. Hitherto it has been found that where any works of magnitude have been executed in Egypt, the preponderance of contracts has been secured by - European Arms. As regards the erection of buildings, as distinguished from other works, the Company will be in the favourable position of being able to complete them from basement to 1 roof, including their equipment throughout with electrical and sanitary appliances ; thus theprofits on minor contracts can be secured to the Company. There is & great demand for small residential houses in Cairo and Alexandria, and a wide field is open to the Company to erect small houses in suitable localities, according to the plans and requirements of purchasers, and 1 to have the cost of erection secured by Mortgages payable in installments, with the usual ; interest thereon, extending over a period to suit the convenience of clients.

The Company will in the first instance acquire and amalgamate the businesses i carried on by the well-known firms of Engineers, Contractors and Builders, Messrs. McClure & Dorling, of Alexandria, and Messrs. G. L. Pezzi & Co., of Cairo and Alexandria. Both firms are highly respected, and have been entrusted with numerous important contracts by—amongst others—the Egyptian Government, H. H. The Khedive, the British Government, the Egyptian State Railways Administration, the Prisons Department, the Quarantine Board, the British Schools, the Alexandria Water Company, etc., etc

Messrs. G. L. Pezzi & Co., who have been established since 1865, in addition to their business as Contractors and Builders, carry on the lucrative business of supplying the building trade with paints, papers, and other building materials and requisite.

The immediate vendors to and promoters of the Company are Messrs. Barclay, Hinks & Co., of Cairo (hereinafter called "the Vendors"), who have agreed to acquire the said businesses from their respective proprietors with a view to the re-sale thereof to the Company at a profit, the particulars of which appear from the statements hereinafter contained. The proprietors, Mr. T. McClure, Mr. S. Dorling and Mr. G. L. Pezzi. who will be the first Managing Directors of the Company, show their confidence in the Company’s future, not only by taking six-sevenths of their proportion of the purchase price, other than the valuation of the stock and plant, entirely in folly paid shares, but they have also agreed, by the undermentioned Agreements (4) and (5) that daring the first five years their salaries as Managing Directors shall not be payable in by a year in which the Company shall not have earned profits sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 percent. on the initial paid-up capital, and have farther agreed to retain a holding of 10 000 shares daring their term of office, and to deposit the certificates of such shares with the Company.

Both businesses will be taken over by the Company as going concerns as from the 1st day of October, .1905, and the Company will have the benefit of all profit realised from that date. The property to be transferred to the Company will include, besides the goodwills of the two businesses, the benefit of all pending contracts, the benefit of the existing agreements for the business premises, the book debts from the 1st October, 1905, and the office furniture, fixtures and fittings.

The purchase price for the sale of the said goodwills, the pending contracts, the agreements f >r tenancy of the business premises, book debts, office furniture, fixtures and fittings has been fixed by the under-mentioned Agreement 1 at £40,000. The stock-in-trade, plant and appliances will be purchased at a valuation. The Vendors have agreed to pay the preliminary expenses of the Company down to the first general allotment of shires other than Brokerage, stamps on Share Warrants, and stamp duty on the Sale Agreement. Such preliminary expenses are estimated at £2,500. The value of the goodwills is fixed at £30.000. The Vendors have also agreed in consideration of the farther payment of £6,000 in cash to subscribe or procure subscriptions for 75,000 shares in the Company ; 12,000 of these shares have been subscribed for by the Memorandum of Association. The paid amounts payable to the Vendors, namely £46.000 altogether, will be paid and satisfied as to £25,000 by the allotment of 25,009 shares and the balance of £21,000 in cash.

div.head: MANAGEMENT
div.p: The Company will hive the advantage of the expert services of Mr. Thomas McClure, Mr. Stanley Dorling and Mr. G. L Pezzi, who have consented to act as Managing Director! for a period of five years at a salary of £700 per annum each, payable only as above stated, after profits have been earned sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 percent. off the original capital of the Company. Messrs. McClure, Dorling and Pezzi have all beau in Egypt a great number of years daring which time they have been engaged in engineering and building contracts of all kinds, and have acquired an exceptional knowledge of the peculiar and special requirements of the engineering and building industry of that country.

div.head: THE UPPER NILE
div.p: BAHR-EL-GHAZAL QUESTION.
A BELGIAN VIEW.

A Belgian writer who is well known through his articles on the Congo contributes to the “Mouvement Geographique’’ a special article embodying the opinion of all the officers who are acquainted with the Bahr-el-Ghazal, and have been interviewed in regard to its econo­mic value. It is a poor, arid, desert region without future, they say, and it would seem that its sole merit consists in the fact that it is watered by the old Nile, the father of rivers.

For the past fifteen years the Congo Free State has devoted to its expansion towards the Nile the best of its strength, its ablest officers, and considerable sums of money, exceeding certainly over two million francs annually. To this undertaking is due the disastrous Dhanis Expedition and the rebellion of the Batetela, the repression of which cost so many lives and so large a sum. To it likewise is due the succession of regrettable diplomatic cot diets, first with Franco, then with Germany, and just now with England. Why should all this be ? Of what use to the Congo Free State can be tbe possession of the morasses and the arid plains of the Babr el-Ghazal ?

Moreover, a Brussels newspaper prints the following: "In well-informed circles it is asserted that owing to the ob tinacy of the king, war is perhaps going to break out be­tween the Congolese and Egyptian troops. This shall not be, and we here declare that Prince Albert does in no way share the ideas of the king, his uncle, with regard to the exploita­tion of the Congo. The matter is becoming extremely serious ; it is no good concealing the fact, and hence it is wise to look ahead at once,”

The following expo-ition, from the Belgian point of view, of the situation created by the presence of a Congo’ese post in a disputed dis­trict of the Upper Nile region, gives the Bel­gian aspect of the question :

The alarmist despatches and articles in Lon­don papers on the subject of the situation of affairs in the Bahr-el Ghazal Province have been read in Belgium with surprise and regret, surprise at so great a storm being raised about a matter that calls for calm and temperate dis­cussion, regret at the British nation being so easily incited against a neighbouring and friend­ly people. There is the Entente Cordiale with France, but, sorely the English people are no going to forget the much older and unbroken Entente with the races of Belgium. It would be easy to answer these sensational assertions by stating that in face of the explicit orders given to the officers commanding the posts in the Lado enclave and on the borders, a collision between Belgian and British representatives is impossible, hot to do so would be to invest them with same of the importance that their authors seek to impart to them. The English public will prefer a single, substantial fact in refutation of these truly absurd allegations. At the moment that they are being asked to believe that a hostile encounter may occur in the Bahr-el-Ghazal, the Congo authorities in Lado are. and have been, receiving their guns and ammunition —in quite reasonable and moderate quantities—across British territory by the Uganda Hail way. The British authorities evidently do not share the appreheraions of the anti-Congo agitators.

It is perfectly true that the Bahr-el-Ghazal question still awaits settlement, but it will be a peaceful, and, Belgians do not doubt, an amicable settlement. The means of such an arrangement are clearly provided either by a voluntary reference by the two Governments to the Hague Tribunal or by the putting into practice of Article XII. of the Berlin Act, which specially provides for the mediation of one or morefriendly Powers, and, failing mediation, for arbitration. The statement recently made to the effect that “ King Leopold would accept no arbitration ” is absolutely incorrect, a d the London Foreign Office is, of course, aware that repeatedly since the Bahr-el-Ghazal ques¬tion was first raised in October. 1898, his Majesty hag proposed that the matter should be sat mitted to either the Hague Court or to arbitration. It is the British not the Congo Government that “ would accept no arbitra¬tion." If the reader wishes for specific autho¬rity for this statement he will find it in the Congo State’s reply of the 17th of September, 1903, to hia Majesty’s Government’s despatch of the 8th of August of the same year. The following extract from that document is relevant to the point:

“ The Government of the State has not ceased for its part to extol arbitration fir inter­national disagreements which admitted of its application. For instance, it would be glad to see the divergencies of view that have arisen about the lease of the territories of the Bahr-el- Ghazal submitted to arbitration.”

It seems tons in Belgium that the incidents of the last two years and a half have established the wisdom of that view, and the hope is strongly felt that at last the two Governments will come to some agreement for the settlement of a dispute that has been left too long neglect­ed or, at all events, without a solution. It is not by journalistic polemics that this important matter is to be arranged, and, therefore, I studiously avoid entering upon the controversial side of the question, but by reference to a properly-constituted tribunal or to sd arbitrator Tally invested with the authority to which both Bides will bow. There is, indeed, one other practical alternative, which is, that the British and Congo Governments should come to terms, but this solution is for the present dubious.

div.head: CAIRO'S GEOLOGICAL MUSEUM
div.p: One of the results of the development of activity in the Survey Department of recent years, has been the establishment of a geologi­cal museum at Cairo, the catalogue of which, compiled by Mr. W. F Hume, D Sc., A.R.S.M.. F.G.S., has just been published by the National Printing Department. The Geological Museum, which was opened to public inspection on December 1st, 1901, has been founded with the object of preserving permanent records of the geological products of Egypt in relation to their (1) economic and practical use ;(2) the nature of the minerals and rocks ; (3) the past life- record of Egypt. Bearing this classification in mind, the rooms devoted respectively to these aims are as follows : east room, ground floor, Economic Gallery ; east room, upper floor, Stratigraphical Gallery ; central room, upper floor, Palaeontological Gallery; west room, upper floor, Petrographical Gallery. The west room, ground floor, is at present used as a storage and work room, a curator’s room and laboratory completing the museum. Room 1 is mainly devoted to the building stones, records of un­derground structure obtained in boring opera­tions, days used in pottery, salts of economic value and rocks associated with minerals of value. Room 2 contains a large collection of the invertebrate fossils arranged according to rela­tive age. Room 3 should be specially visited, as it contains unique vertebrate remains from the Fayoum. Room 4 contains the mineral and rock collections. The Museum is open from 1st October to 30th April, 8 30 a.m. to 4 p.m May to 30 h September, 8.0 a.m. to 2.0. p.m., except Fridays and Government holidays.

In the central ball of the ground floor is the sale room for the Survey Department cata­logues and maps, including the memoirs of the geological survey. The remaining space in the central hall i3 devoted t) an exhibit of fossil silicified trees from the Fayoum. and in the table-case is an interesting series of flint imple­ments from the Fayoum and Nile Valley.
The growth of the museum demanded a catalogue and the present compilation should be of great use to all who interest themselves in the geology of Egypt and the Nile Valley

div.head: THE NILE AND ITS TRIBUTARIES
div.p: WILD ELEPHANT LIFE.
An eloquent description of the elephant in the wild stats is given in an article in “Black­wood” describing a voyage up the upper reaches of the ‘‘Nile and its tributaries.” It says :—

“The Sobat is a digression, but it is worth while to take a glance up this wild river, for it courses through a great gems country. We recall a clear, cool morning on that tortuous stream. From the upper deck there is a sudden cry of fil, and up we swarm to see over the top of the long, thick grass which covers the barks and spreads for miles on either hand. We gain the planking and realise that it is something of a shock to get a first sight and a close view of real wild elephants. Yet there can be no doubt about them.

“Not a quarter of a mile away humping up above the sea of yellowish-grey, are three ob­jects which look like three huge moving masses of back indiarubber. But indiarubber never moved, never swung and lurched, as these great bodies swing and lurch, never —yes, it is so ; a vast spreading ear was flapped yonder, there goes a trunk sticking straight oat in front of what is a tusker, for the sun had glinted on his ivory !

“There is something awesome about these mighty quadrupeds, so unconcerned, so peace able, and yet endowed with strength sufficient to tear a stanchion clean out of the steamer, sufficient to easily, smoothly, indifferently force a way through a thick, tangled growth which exhausts a man in ten min a tee, and swallows him up as though he were a pigmy.

“They feel closer to us, and we can see the white paddy birds fluttering about them and perching on their backs, busy after the ticks which ding to and suck at these great coarse, bristle-covered hides. How fast they travel, heads to the wind, taking no notice of ns, lords of the prairie—for what beast can hope to cope with such bulk, such ponderous weight, such terrible tusks, and so marvellous an organ of prehension ?

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: MR. WALTER GREG.

The death has taken place, at Assouan, of Mr. Walter Greg, of Lee Hall, Prestbury He was 'born at Bollington in 1851, and was admitted a solicitor in 1875. He became a partner in the firm’ of Messrs. Cunliffe and Greg, of London, in 1880 and bad been head of the firm since 1899. He was also a notary public and a member of the Council of the Manchester Incorporated Law Society. Mr. Greg was Under Sheriff of Lancashire in 1883-4 and in 1888 9 ; he was also Under Sheriff for Cheshire in 1886 7, and again in 1889-90. Some thirty years ago he was an active member of the Manchester Football Club, and had played in international matches. He had taken a prominent part in the introduction of the game of lacrosse into the Manchester district, and in 1877 played for England against Scot­land. .In the neighbourhood of his home in Cheshire he had taken great interest in ioo&l affairs, and was chairman of the Mottram Parish Conned and a manager of the school.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do pot hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in s spirit of fair play to mil, to permit—within certain necessary limits—free discussion.
THE OPENING UP OF THE HOLY LAND.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette

Pear Sir,—Iu your issue of the 16th January appeared an article entitled “The Opening up of the Holy Land,” This article has a curiously ambiguous character. On one face of it it looks like one of those deceptive advertisements that are occasionally presented under the guise of an article in order to catch the reader’s eye that has come to torn away instinctively from everything under the shape of an "ad,” so obtrusive has advertising material become in these latter days. On the other face of it there is the pose of the enthusiastic tourist. But whatever may be the real nature of the article, certain statements and certain omissions in it cannot but provoke the most reluctant criti­cism.

The author of the article under review states that the Hamburg-American Line has its little steamer on the Sea of Galilee, while, he adds, from Semak on the southern end of the lake the railway will be used for the journey to Damascus. Although the writer is not exactly in a position to judge whether these statements are correct or not, yet be has it from an unimpeachable authority, whose statement gains: strength from the fact that he has very recently been on the spot, that there is no steamer that plies on the waters of the Sea of Galilee, while as regards travelling by rail from Semak to Damascus, it is well-known that the Hedjaz. line from Deraa until that station is not yet quite complete, as far as passenger traffic is concerned, and although the Haiffa-Deraa branch has been inaugurated some time, this has been done in anticipation to invest the event with the honour of the Saltan’s anniversary, and it may, indeed, be a month before the journey from Semak to Damascus by the Hedjaz Railway will be practicable. Indeed the running of the trains from Semak to Haiffa is now very irre-gular. Only a short time ago some passengers had tried the railway between Semak and Da¬mascus and they were left, out at some small halts east of the Jordan, and had to pass the night in hats wherein they suffered consider* able hardships from cold and vermin.

There are unmistakable signs in the article showing that if the author thereof is not di­rectly inspired by the Hamburg-American Line, be draws at least inspiration from that group of German patriots who under imperial encouragement are flaunting the idea of Germany’s overruling greatness and its conquering in­fluence especially in Turkey. And as every attempt on the part of Germany at the assertion of its influence abroad has in moat oases been curiously associated with a disparag­ing attack on British rights and feelings, the omissions in the article find an explanation. The fact is too well-known to need more than mere mention, that the pioneer of tourist or­ganisation in Syria and Palestine is the world- renowned firm of Thos. Cook & Son. The writer, be it said from now, has not the least connection with or interest in that firm, but it seems to him, as it must seem to every right- minded person, so unfair, not to say ungrateful, that in writing about the mode of travelling and its development in the Holy Land, a firm that has played the most prominent idle there­in should be so slightingly overlooked. The author of the article goes indeed so far as to attribute things achieved with the assistance of Thos. Cook & Son. to the Hamburg-American Line, when he says that the hotel at Tiberias has been modernized and enlarged by the help of the Hamburg-American Line. It is indeed doubtful whether such a respectable steamship company would care to S9e persons attributing to it achievements that are not its own.

The author could have rejoiced just as glee­fully over the initial attempts of the Hamburg- American Line to improve the mode of travelling in the Holy Laud, without overrat­ing so much their importance as to seek to throw even the giant figure of Cook in utter darkness. Is not the Hamburg-American Line indebted in a way to the initiative of Cook, that has been the chief and we may say the first factor in the development of tourism that forms such an important item in the revenue of first class steamship companies like the Hamburg-American Line? Cook may have been guided by no altruistic feelings and humanitari­an motives when he conceived and carried out his magnificent programmes of travel, bat the actual result is there to prove that the good that he has, intentionally or not, caused to the land is incalculable. One may without exagger­ation say that Cook has been one of the that he has, intentionally or not, caused to the land is incalculable. One may without exagger­ation say that Cook has been one of the strongest factors in the introduction of ci­vilization or — to attenuate the phrase — of civilised modes of life and the accompaniment of a certain measure of prosperity. One has but to travel in Syria and in those parts not includ­ed in Cook’s tourist programmes to see the enor­mous difference, not only in the conditions of travel between those parts that are trodden and those that are not trodden by Cook, but also in the general condition of the people and the country.

I cannot close these lines without commenting upon the patronising manner in which Germans of imperialist tendencies look upon and speak of Turkey. They seem to regard it already a9 their heritage or on the highway to such a consummation under the aegis of the Kaiser. The author of the article naively de­clares that a considerable improvement in the means of transport in Palestine and Syria has been noticeable since the trip of the German Emperor to Jerusalem in 1898 and that the continued interest he still shows in their advance has induced the Turkish authorities to remove some of the more objectionable inconveniences, and to urge forward the construc­tion of the railways that had been so long projected. The whole thing, especially to a man living in Turkey, is so amusing.—I am, etc.
A Syrian Reader.
Damascus.

div.head: SPORTS AND PLAY
div.p: HOCKEY AT SUEZ.
E. T. C. v. H. M. S. KING ALFRED.

This match, which was played on Thursday, was arranged at short notice, hot nevertheless resulted in a very good game. The combination of the home team told from the start, the forward being well supported by Menzies at centre-half. The visitors, on the other hand, being out of practice, did not settle down to the game at once, with the result that the B.T.C. forwards got away, and from a centre by Mansell on the Tight wing, Harrison scored the first goal. Shortly afterwards Mansell added two more for the homesters. The visitors then got through with a combined rash, bat the goal was disallowed for offside. After half tame the visitors were getting together more, hot the home defence proved equal to the occasion. The home forwards then got to work again, and Harrison scored twice in quick succession. The visitors made several rashes and after game good passing, Marks scored with a hard shot. From the bully with another dash .Marks notched a second point for the visitors just before time. This left the E.T.C. winners by five goals to two. The E.T.C. were represented by : goal, Massey ; backs, Battiseom.be and Templeman ; halves, Bentley, Menses, and Evans forwards, Mansell, Norman, Harrison, Chivers, and Harris.
